Made again using Barbados rum. Perfect. Not too sweet with a wonderful citrus flavour.
The choice of rum will make a difference. You need one which is not adulterated by sugar syrup.
While I love the funk of Jamaican, Martinique, and Haitian rhum, it will through this cocktail off balance. Stick with Barbados.
A very good cocktail, but not my favorite - I thought that the curacao made it a bit too orangey.
The most outstanding daiquiri I tried, though clearly your falernum is half of the magic.
Terrific! Enough rum that I could enjoy the funky nose using Havana Club Añejo Clásico. The rum, citrus and other flavors were in perfect balance. Nice upgrade in complexity from a standard daiquiri.

Great flavor profile present. The rum and the Falernum work great together. I will second the thanks of John Hinojos about this site, it has greatly expanded my joy/knowledge of making cocktails for friends.
Being a longtime favourite cocktail, I used funky Clement VO rhum agricole today and 2 drops Umami Bitters. Wow that is really another step forward!
A classic. Subtle but also flavoursome and fragrant with all the elements working well together. Made with Havana Club 3, Taylors Falernum and Giffard Cruracao.
You can't go wrong with mint and champagne! What a great Mojito twist. Love it.
My favourite cocktail, perhaps because it’s what my fiancé and I drank to celebrate our engagement in Paris in Cafe Panis overlooking Notre Dame. FYI it’s lethal on an empty stomach, be warned!
Very good high-end mojito. Champaign adds an interesting touch.
This is really lovely, though I do recommend slapping the mint before adding to the glass and muddling with the simple syrup and lime juice to bring out even more mint flavor.
Lovely. I added 1.25ml of maraschino syrup.

Toast to the Queen
Lovely cocktail
Wonderful cocktail. Toasted the Queen on her birthday.
Thanks to those commenters who suggested gin as an alternative to vodka. In which case, we substituted lime for the lemon, but at 15ml.

Is the Aperol switched to Select? I thought it was Aperol. No matter, I happen to have also Select at home.
Any thoughts on the choice of bitter sweet?
I suspect Select is displayed as you have added Select to Your Ingredients, so our database thinks that's the brand you'd prefer to use.
Brilliantly fresh and fruity. Perfectly balanced. Five stars - why not?!
great but way too much foam
You must be really good with the egg white thing lol
I made the drink per the recipe and it's very enjoyable - balanced; not too sweet nor tart. I think a splash of grapefruit bitters would go a long way.
You could sub out Vodka for Gin for a Gin Ruby, more complex

This is funny, I started pouring gin in the tins and at the same time my husband pulled up the recipe and told me it was with vodka, so poured the gin back in the bottle, went all over the place lol and used vodka. Most enjoyable cocktail, giving it a 5.
If you have super fresh grapefruit and good quality vodka etc I think there’s already plenty of complexity with ingredients as is IMO.
Excellent as a aperitif. Wonderfully sour with the various flavours of the citrus. Perfect for sipping and good conversation.
This is very refreshing. My first experience with Cappellietti. I am very pleased with it. This is a very nice sour. Will make again.

Definitely a post-meal cocktail. Might be because we used a cheaper triple sec, but it started out very sweet before having a much needed hum of sourness and bitterness from the Citrus-infused vodka and grapefruit juice. Pretty good!

Very nice. Being we like our cocktails drier, we omitted the sugar syrup and put in a splash of grenadine to add a little more pink (our pink grapefruit juice was not very pink). Nice with a hint of sweetness. Would probably put in a splash of pomegranate juice next time also.

Made with Probitas (aka Veritas). I found this to be good, but also unremarkable. It's indeed well-balanced, and quite tasty, it's just not anything special. I'd rather have a regular daiquiri, or a (Trader Vic's) Mai Tai if I want orgeat.

Very almond flavour forward. Tended to be a bit sweet, but we added 4 drops of Bob's Difford's Daiquiri Bitters and it did lessen the sweetness. The bitters also added some flavour notes which were not part of the original cocktail. Went wonderful with a beef and rice stir fry.
Perfectly balanced. Go easy with the built in dasher on the Peychaud bottle. I definitely got too much for my two dashes. On the dry side, rich, intense and fruity. Even a little smokey in character.
The orange twist is important in providing a relieving lift here.
I'm confused... it's called the "Ruby Manhattan", but then uses tawny rather than ruby port.
I assume referring to the colour. The tawny port definitely works.
Not a Manhattan fan, but this alone may make me say otherwise.
Have you tried the cherry Manhattan? Especially if your tastes extend to sweet things.
Of all the Manhattan variations I have tried. This is the best for my taste. Not overly sweet and perfectly balanced.
love variations on the Manhattan - will try this with maybe a triple sec - as i am not buying another one off liquor for the apricot
Ah, but with the apricot liqueur, you can also have the related (and delicious) Sunset Park. Or just add a dash to a nice martini.
Good looking. Apricot Jammy without being overly sweet. Decent drink deserving more reviews. I liked it.
FML. This is top drawer, much nicer and punchier than the vodka alt

As I have a bottle of Cranberry juice needed to be used it’s cranberry cocktail day today. Enjoying this one much. Not sure if this juice is sweetened, I have a feeling it’s not and could have done with 5ml of sugar syrup. Night cocktail is going to be Nelson’s Blood No 2. And tomorrow a standard Cosmo (Dale Degroff, the only one that worked for me)
Great alternative to a Cosmo. Found it a bit on the sweet side for me, but I find most Cosmos are I would add a little more lime juice for my taste, but if you are a Cosmo lover, leave it alone.
Sure wish I could print this recipe or be allowed to copy the text. Guess I'll have to dream about what it tastes like. Nice user experience!
We pull the recipe up on a tablet or phone. Works great for us.

Thought I would have a tinker with this recipe, since I had some cranberry juice. Swapped Mezcal for Tequila, curacao for triple sec and used a flamed grapefruit zest garnish. Not Rude anymore, Profane perhaps, or just Cheeky!
Liked this very much, it hints of ginger and strong lime. Quite delicious. (Who knew I would be putting ginger in my drinks!). Might experiment with ginger syrup.
Great hints of ginger, slightly sweet, and nice mixtures of flavours. Would be great anytime, but perfect in the cooler weather. A blend of a cosmo and a Margarita. Perfect.
Marvellously smooth. A perfect start or end to a night
I made this with Mezcal (over blanco tequila) last night, and it might actually be an improvement.
Marvelous both for it's simplicity and resulting complexity. And the Difford's Margarita Bitters are indespensible . Will try the London Gypsy next.

Definitely an underrated cocktail. I actually make this 50ml/25ml (ie. same ratio, just slightly bigger), otherwise the total of 60ml of liquid looks a bit sad in my Nick and Nora glasses. I'm using El Major blanco.
Agreed. Measures were a tad stingy - I've upped to 45 and 22.5.
Very, very nice cocktail. Interesting mix of the tequila and DOM gives a nice honey, tequila, and herbal taste. Went perfectly with our dinner.
I made this but accidentally used a Blanco Tequila. Really loved it!!

A good cocktail, but not a notably better than a more traditional espresso martini, or the Black Espresso (recipe on the website). If you are looking for a rum/espresso/PX recipe to try - try the Black Espresso first.

Used Havana Club 7 yo and Borghetti. The only perceived fault I can suggest is the roasty and nutty nuances of the espresso are ever so slightly muted. It's got a surprising degree of dryness to it, or maybe I diluted it a touch too much. At any rate, it's a marginally more interesting Espresso Martini, but not exactly preferable to one.
For me this is improved with a touch more PX, tried with coffee beans and raisins but rum soaked raisins and a square of RnR choc wins for me.

Like the two other comment, I found that the balance of this drink was a bit off. I tried to add a bit of amaretto like mister Hinojos had suggested. the mix was better but a bit flat, for my taste. So I tested with a bit more of Maraschino and some orange flower water, like mister Dworkin tried. I liked that version a bit more.
This is nice, but it seems to be missing the almond flavour. It seems to be overshadowed by the Maraschino and Absinthe. Could increase the Orgeat or maybe add some Amaretto.
Many thanks for the feedback. I've revisited and dramatically rebalanced this recipe as a result.
The balance isn't right. Double orgeat and add more orange flower water improves it
interesting way to dress up some milk
Great milk cocktail that's not overly sweet. Seems like you could have some fun trying it with different funky Jamaican rums.
Still wonderful. Made with 3/4 oz Barbados white rum, 3/4 oz Barbados gold rum, and 1/2 oz Demerara rum. It was outstanding. A bit more flavourful due to the various rums, but a great alternative.
We found this outstanding. Use 1/2 Barbados white and 1/2 Barbados gold rum. Like all Daisy cocktails, it was wonderfully sour with a hint of lemon and spices.
would recommend making it with a sweeter vs dry light rum
Exquisite.

The system here suggested my Hamilton 151 (eye roll) for the float, and it obliterated the egg foam. The drink wasn't bad with it, and I was pleased it wasn't all that sweet. Maybe something to revisit to test different rum combos.

Being a big rum drinker was looking forward to this, but found it just OK. Nice but was a bit underwhelmed with this cocktail. Agreed with Andre that it needed more aged rum. Seemed to work a bit better mixing in the overproof rum to add some depth of flavour to the cocktail. Did drink the full cocktail, but there are other rum cocktails much better.
Liked it better with a full shot of aged rum!
Quite sweet, like it a lot with 2 cl fresh lime juice

I used a frozen strawberry; figured it would add to the chill.
Am I actually supposed to taste the citrus slices and fruit?
No shaking, no muddling...
The fruit is more for garnish than flavour.
Flavor-wise, it's tasty and has potential. My house-made syrup probably wasn't as concentrated and sweet as it needed to be, which left the mouthfeel a little too airy for my taste.
I've used Cola syrup from Maison Meneau near Bordeaux. Well known here and as good as Giffard or Monin syrup
Made this with Bolivar 8 and Plantation OFTD Overproof. Simply delicious. 5 star +.

The overproof rum really does make this. Just did a 500ml batch freezer door version using Doorly's 12, Wry and Nephew white over proof, Bitter Truth falernum and coconut water for dilution (pour straight from the bottle over ice, so dilution is needed for a batched cocktail). Really nice. I'm going to experiment with adding Stiggin's Fancy, too.

I really like the Maple Rum Old-Fashioned here on DG, but this is an interesting option if you want a boozier rum-based old-fashioned. I used Appleton Estate 8 and Wray & Nephew, so there was a fair amount of "funk", but overall enjoyable and as expected.
R.L. Seale's 10 | Don Q | JDT Velvet ... didn't care for it with this rum.
better with cane island guatemala

I used 6cl Plantation 3 Star, 1cl Orgeat, 1.25ml Bogart's Bitters (thanks to the amazing Difford's jigger), inspired by Jerry Thomas' Japanese Cocktail. I put a lime slice in the glass before stirring instead of a zest & it was stunning. Would recommend

Still love this since I really, really like rum. Used a Barbados aged rum and a Demerara 151 overproof. Did cut back on the sugar syrup by half (I was making two cocktails so it was easy). As before this was delightful. Liked using the darker overproof as it added more flavour and complexity to the cocktail Still a 5 for me.

Really very good. Having not made a rum old fashioned before I was drawn to the idea of blending rums to achieve a complete drink. I have made this as specced, yet it works very well with a wide range of rums if you play with the ratios: I really didn't think Pussers naval with Barbancourt 8* had any right to work. The Falernum (or equivalent) really is critical to success I think, along with the right garnish.
Used 2oz Ron Izalco 130 proof (Maisano's store pick), subbed agave nectar as the sweetener. Everything else as written above; beautiful.
Probably the best and one of the simplest cocktails of all time. Absolutely divine flavour, this takes you off to an evening on the beach where ever you are.
Meant to add - you can shake the nuts off this and make it a tall drink and the rum still cuts thru
Used 2/3 White overproof Wray and Nephew and 1/3 Lemon Hart 151 Demerara. Wow. Big rum punch (no pun intended).
So, effectively, a daiquiri w/ ango on the rocks...

Fantastic - I used Wray & Nephew Navy Strength (one of my favorites) - this cocktail allows the highlights of the rum to shine while boosting the sweetness and a bit of citrus as well. Excellent cocktail - highly recommended!!
Oops - I meant Smith & Cross Navy Strength, not Wray & Nephew - sorry for any confusion this may have caused.

Made this with 45 ml Wray & Nephew, 15 ml lime juice, 30 ml 2:1 sugar syrup, 24 drops Angostura, 60 ml chilled water. Very tasty. The lime, sugar, bitters, & water help soften the edges of the rum without taking center stage. Very flavorful. Seems like a great option for introducing someone to Wray & Nephew. Also seems great for a hot summer day!

Finally gave this a shot after having it on my list for a while. I think the fact that it's diluted with so much water initially made me hesitant but I gotta say, this was fantastic. I upped the rum to 2 oz and added about 1/4 oz of allspice dram on my second pour and that was great, as well. It doesn't taste diluted it's just a refreshing long drink with a ton of flavor. My new go-to when I need to whip up something easy that still tastes great.
Really nice, I like all the punch recipe's though. For me 2 dashes angostura is was too much for the wray & Nephew I used for te drink. Next time I will put 1 dash in.
Brilliant, thanks Simon.

Replacing the screwtop on a bitters bottle with a Dartdash does expose the bitters to oxygenation and will accelerate the evaporation of alcohol. If using a bottle in a few months then not an issue. Otherwise, perhaps replace the screwcap between uses. (If you do use a Dartdash then use a knife to prise out the plastic dasher insert in the bottle.)
Would this work as well with a normal strength white rum or does this have to be overproof?
You'd have to massively up the volume of the rum but it's not just the balance of alcohol to other ingredients, it's the flavour that overproof rum provides that makes the drink.
Hits like a truck except the truck is carrying a neutron star and is covered in spikes. A delicious truck.

This is a perfect cocktail for those who want a rum forward cocktail. Made as described and found the cocktail very flavourful and refreshing. Was nice and warming on a cold winter night, but would be cooling on a hot day. Will try again with other overproof rums/rhums in my collection. Definitely on my favourites for this life-time rum drinker.

I had to create an account to add my two sense and that is... This is a very loose and bizzare addition. Ti-punch deserves its own place on the top with rhum agricole. Planteurs punch another spot on the podium with fresh juice. But to add angos to what is essentially a daiquiri, I'm a bit put off on the whole thing. Overproof rum has its valour, but to add refined sugar or any sort or ice without asking deserves a proper slap on the wrists. I would never dare serve such a drink. JMHO
When I tried this the very intense ester notes of the rum did. let me think it could benefit from some oaky backbone. But of course, as always, this remains a matter of taste.
In this photo the liquid in the glass appears quite dark for just only 2 dashes of Ango. Could it be that this was made with dark rather than with white rum?
Have to add, making this to check the colour was a reminder of how delicious this is. It needs the full 15ml of sugar and the added water.
Good spot. The image is way too dark. We may have confused with another cocktail. I'll add it to my list to re-shoot.
Superb. Dialled back the syrup to suit my taste and it totally hit the spot.

I have had a Rum Runner in many of the existing tiki bars in California. I also have many vintage tiki cocktail books and this recipe is the same (or similar) to those recipes.
As with most tiki cocktails, I find them a bit sweet. We added a Demerara 151 float. Lessened the sweetness and added a bit more of the rum kick.
Couldn’t really get on with the blackberry. Removed, and replaced with 15ml of a creamy banana liqueur I had on hand. A dusting of grated nutmeg works well.
Nix the grenadine. Reduce the pineapple to 45 ml, the banana liqueur to 22.5 ml. Add two dashes of Peychaud's bitters. There it is! Enjoy.
I honed this down to taste better and fit in a Collins glass. Crushed ice may dilute this to death. If so, then add a little sweetener to drive it.

I made this drink according to these directions, and it came out a little sweet but still very enjoyable. I think it made a difference that I used fresh pressed pineapple juice from a pineapple that I cut up immediately before I made the drink.
A bit too sweet for me. I might skip the grenadine next time, and maybe swap the blackberry liqueur for unsweetened cranberry juice.

Pretty good, but I felt like it was a bit of an in-betweener. Next time I will add more blackberry to see if that tips it in the direction that I was hoping for. Not a bad drink, just not my favorite.
I made it : 1oz Cargo Cult Banana Rum, 1oz dark rum, 1 oz pineapple juice, 1 oz creme de cassis, 1 oz orange juice, 0.5 oz grenadine and 0.5 oz 55% rum
When the sunshine arrives this is my goto and its easily customisable to whatever you have in the cabinet.
This is not very far away from a drink called a Freight Train Swizzle which adds a touch of Green Chartreuse and leaves out the lemon juice. Either way you can’t go wrong!
Bacardi 8 year worked well for this. Prominent rum flavor, but balanced out by the citrus/clove/brown sugar/bitters. Great easy-to-make rum drink.
Delicious - rum leads the flavor, and is underscored by the Demerara syrup. Falernum and bitters add depth of flavor, and the lime (softened by the lemon) give a citrus brightness.
Made this with diplomatico reserva exclusiva. Gorgeous! The garnishes really add to the whole experience. The drink is dark and sticky but smells fresh because of the mint/orange.
Added 45ML pineapple, for a easier sipping drink. Used my 12 YO rum but too much going on for it to shine, next time will use 6 year old :)
Made with El Dorado 12 YO rum, i used turbinado syrup instead of demerara. amazing Drink. Cheers
Made this with Mount Gay gold, cut the sugar syrup in half, added a float of 151 Demerara rum. It was wonderful.
Pleasant first use of Falernum and swizzling but a little on the mild side. Look forward to a Green Swizzle next time.

Quite sweet and boozy, yet it is a well balanced drink and I liked it. I shaked with crush ice to have more dilution, added a dash of saline solution, and used Martin Miller Gin and Rhum agricole overproof. Great, but I will try next time with Jamaican overproof rum.

I didn't have any grenadine to hand, so increased the syrup to 10 ml and used 30 ml pineapple juice with non-wet ice.
This created a truly dangerous cocktail that I allowed the funk to shine with depth brought by the gin, all brought together with the pineapple. The head from the pineapple made it quite an attractive serve and I will certainly be making more of this riff as well as trying the original recipe when I have grenadine again.
This is wonderful. Well balanced with sweet and sour while being able to taste the rum and gin.

This is an incredible cocktail. Arguably my favorite that uses either pomegranate juice or orgeat. The combination and balance of each here is sublime and surprising. The orgeat (Giffard) is most definitely present, near front and center, but not too sweet. I opted to add 3 drops of rose water into the shake. This drink looks and tastes fantastic, but I can certainly understand it's not for everyone. (7 Jul 2023, 3:58p)
Delicious and pleasantly sour. I couldn't really detect the orgeat beyond a general sweetness, but it probably contributed to the overall effect. Pomegranate juice is lovely stuff.
Enjoyed this cocktail, nice balance of sweet and sour.
Made with Zubrowka and some other, not St George pear liqueur. Lovely and fruity and not overwhelming.
So fresh and bright! Delightful combination of fruit flavors supported by a brilliant vodka base. It may go down a little too easy, so take care!

Incredible! I was intrigued by the unusual pairing of liqueurs but was delighted to find how tasty this was. I bulked up the vodka by 15 ml and added 15 ml of cognac for a little more body. Magnificent stuff
As you know, Simon, we think this is one delicious drink! I hope others will as well!
Very good drink. I had some less expensive Leroux Kirschwasser from long ago so wondering if a fine Kirsch might be better?
Well shaken I found this dry and brisk- went down in three! Used sangue morlacco as it’s what I had. Not sure how it might impact the final result?

This was an "interesting" cocktail. Can definitely taste the cherries upfront with the almonds slightly present. Has slight herbal tones at the end (where from, I don't know. Maybe pepperiness from the Kirsh?) and was fairly dry and not sweet.

This was perfect for the occasion. We were having a New Orleans style dinner and needed a cocktail. This was perfect. The tastes of the cocktail went with the spiciness of the food. Was concerned it may be a bit sweet, so we use 2 oz of vodka instead of 1 1/2. Was great.
Forgot to mention in my previous comment that I used Johnnie Walker Black, Drambuie, & Galliano Espresso.

This isn't necessarily a drink that'll knock your socks off, but if you want a somewhat creamy, smokey/herbal dessert/nightcap, this is a solid choice. It's not too creamy/heavy/fatty nor too smokey/herbal. Coffee is mild, too. I wanna say there's a hint of "chocolate" in there... Slightly astringent. Could maybe try a small amount of sugar syrup if you want something more on the dessert side of things, but either way, a fairly well balanced easy sipper.
definitely doesnt need to be sweeteened imo but then again i hate drambuie
A successful marriage which for my tastes could do with a bit more coffee and a little less whisky.
Superb: Spicy, nutty, salty, smokey and subtle all balanced with a freshening zesty orange aroma. Wow. (I used blood orange peel for the zest.) Will be returning to this gem. Thanks again Mr Difford.

Havana 7 as all the mentions in green color are just paid product placements and in 95% of the cases a bad choice (or at least far from ideal) for the drinks, sadly. As he states later, it's originally with Zacapa 23. I'd recommend El Dorado 12 or 15 for example.
Just made this with Loch Lomond peated grain whisky. Got cherry bubblegum. I quite enjoyed it.

Not being a big fan of Scotch which is too smoky, used single malt from Speyside and the midlands. There was just enough smoky taste to be interesting, but not overwhelm the cocktail. If you like the smoky, I would use the Islay.
Definitely improves with dilution.
Wow. This was a great margarita. Taking the advice of other posts we did a splash of water before shaking. It was perfect. A keeper.
Simple and magnificent. Great to find a cocktail that gets better with time.
Very nice. I like an alcohol forward cocktail but this one definitely needed the water from shaking and a bit more.
I recommend to try it by replacing Scotch with Rye. 2:1 Rye:Drambuie +2 dash Angostura Bitters; just perfect!
Did not try the cocktail (no Drambuie available), but what in the world is the picture? How would it be possible to get pink on a Rusty Nail? Hilarious to me!
I am sure that is just lighting. ?
We do like to amuse! Obviously, wrong image has replaced the original. Please bear with us. That said, adding bitters will colour, more the wrong glass and garnish that troubles me.

Love Rusty nails.
I have tried this drink with many different types of scotch and found the Dalmore Port Wood the best for the mix. It adds a nice exotic oaky aroma to it.
Yes at 4:1. The perfect nightcap. Used to drink these with the other bartenders after our shift.
Great cocktail. We did it 4:1 to keep the sweetness down.
I like to use Johnnie Walker Black for these.
My sweet palate prefers a 50/50 mix for this perfect winter drink.
50/50 is my preference too. It's also a great way to introduce whisky to those who struggle with drinking it neat.
4:1 or higher seems better. Or it’s too sweet and cloying
Intriguing. The Islay whisky elevates it from an honeyed apple cocktail to a drink with an edge. One to ponder as you drink.
Great cocktail. I did go with Tom W.'s suggestion and lessened the Islay. Great mixtures of flavours which all blend well.
I prefer slightly less Islay (5ml). It's still smoky, just gives a bit more space for the calvados.
Certainly benefits from adjusting according to how peaty your Islay is.

Before I even got into mixology, two of my go-to drinks to accompany popcorn and a movie were Crown Royal/ginger ale and Hennessy/ginger ale. I think I will have to add this into the rotation - made with Old Forester rye and Canada Dry and it's delicious.
Dad's Hat pretty much overpowers the Fever Tree Refreshingly Light Ginger Ale... That rye does work wonders with Fever Tree Ginger Beer though. A little more sweet and spice required.
This highball is more tasteful than It looks. Not for people with a sweet tooth though.
Just drinking one right now (with James e pepper 1776 rye barrel proof and fever tree ginger beer). Fantastic, spicy, complex and huge coctail.
Is this the right photo? "Serve in a Collins glass [..] into ice-filled glass", yet I see a coupe. :)
Hi Chris, oops, no that's not the right photo, many thanks for spotting it. It should be served in an ice-filled Collins glass...we'll be adding this to our next photoshoot.

Happy to confirm the akvavit experiments described below. I used saxby akvavit by Moe distillery in Estonia, Cynar and Dolin rouge with a lemon twist. Excellent combo and still identifiably a negroni.
I think olives could also be a great garnish option here.

Tried this last night using equal parts of each ingredient as I didn't realise I only had 30ml of rye left in that bottle. I think that's likely an inferior ratio; the spiciness of the rye was not distinct when stirred down. Just a heads-up in case folks are tempted to try that. (And maybe the ratio should be even higher if it's not 100-proof rye?)
I made it with Cynar instead of Campari for a more herbal, less bitter experience. Just great; the spiciness of the rye goes really well with the artichoke weirdness of the Cynar.

I can vouch for the Cynar variation, it complements the Rye well (with Templeton Rye at least.)

Combining this idea with the Sophisticated Dane below, I can verify that Cynar-Akvavit works very well too - the artichoke weirdness balancing the caraway eccentricity (I'm using Aalborg Akvavit); finished with a dash of Bitter Truth Orange bitters.

Also, Hi Melissa, fancy meeting you here! :D
