Really simple, but really good! Great botanical, herbaceous vermouth suprisingly combining so well with pineapple and rum.
I didn't find this terribly sweet, but it has a nice velvety mouthfeel, with a lot of vermouth flavor. The rum recedes into the background. Generally a nice easy drink.

I used a fairly low quality gold rum, Dolin and homemade pomegranate syrup and didn’t find it particularly sweet. The vermouth dominated with the pineapple in the background. Certainly easy drinking and went down quickly on a hot night. Maybe could do with some bitters or something (maybe a different garnish?) to add a little bit more dimension.
We used half gold rum and half 151 Demerara rum to tone back the sweetness. Still a bit sweet, but wonderful on a warm afternoon.
How subtle and complex. Loved it.
Have you changed this recipe? I'm sure I remember it having aromatic bitters and no Maraschino.
Well spotted. I'd forgotten the change and had to refer to my notes. I've added the previous recipe above.

My appreciation of Suze is very much a work in progress. I'd struggle to say I enjoy it but I defintely find it interesting and seem to have got through most of a bottle normally having it with tonic. This cocktail works fantastically is definitely another step towards total acceptance of Suze!

I made this having just enough Cointreau and Suze left to pull it off. The specs to me sounded too sweet, and I felt it was, despite the bracing bite of the Suze. The flavor balance is on point. It might just be a case of dialing down the simple to 7.5 ml. Tough to say, considering the interplay and dominance of acidic citrus and gentian in the aftertaste. Nonetheless, this is going into my catalog. (24 Jun 2023, 10:06a)
This is a lovely, well-balanced bitter cocktail. The addition of egg white is a nice touch, the silky texturing contrasting well with the sharper, herbal flavours.

Lighter in flavor and body than the Sazerac, but still silky smooth and delicious, especially if you enjoy the earthy, vegetal and bitter notes of Suze (I do). I prefer the balance of this cocktail to the somewhat sweeter and heavier Sazerac (although that is excellent as well). I also like that it is a simpler recipe.

Delicious! So as not to waste the absinthe I popped the rinse discard into a shot glass and dropped the expressed lemon round into it, served on the side. The drink itself is superb. Well balanced and bittersweet. Putting the absinthe on the side with the lemon makes me yearn for a Prague revisit...
This is a great cocktail. I agree with Davey Springer's assessment.
Excellent! A comparatively light version of the classic and well worth trying.

cocktail: Suzette au Bal (Suzette at the Ball)

comments.comment: I presented this recipe at my local hostelry as I do not have three of the ingredients at home... The result? A refreshing and tart drink thanks to the gentian liqueur with slightly sweetened lemon. The Mezcal added a smokey touch and, though I could not detect the pear flavour specifically, it was there reinforcing the other flavours. It might be nice to experiment with 20 ml Poire William, if folks want a more forward pear taste. The mixologist was impressed with the concoction, too!
I followed the recipe and ended up with a very strong mezcal flavored drink. Seemed even at 1/2 ounce to overpower the drink or maybe that is the flavor
I agree - I think without ice works really well. A good one to introduce someone gently to gentian based liqueurs as the flavours blend so well here
This is very nice. I was out of Suze so used Bols Genever which I think made it a touch sweeter
This is really good. Love the silky smooth shaken pineapple texture. Try it without ice.
too much peach schnapps for me - I added more lime juice after tasting - next time I will use only 7.5 ml Schnapps .10ml lime juice and touch of sugar syrup .
I Really liked this. It is great for an aperitif. However, we did leave out the sugar syrup. Made the drink less sweet and very refreshing.
Had this again. Again wonderful. Did try with a small float of anejo tequila which was wonderful.

Very good and interesting variation. At least using Tequila blanco I would suggest to up the punch liqueur and even possibly add a bit sugar syrup. As in every Margarita some salt solution helps additional lifting the flavours.

I live in San Diego, so we have tasted lots of different margaritas. Tried this one as we just got some Swedish Punsch. It was outstanding. Has that typical margarita taste, but with the added flavours of the Swedish Punsch. All work well together and produce a cocktail that is way too easy to drink.

This is an outstanding version of a margarita (go ahead and salt that rim if you like). Kudos to Simon for thinking to sub Curaçao with Swedish Punsch. It complements reposado in a wonderful way. No sweetener necessary.
Delicious. First time to mix a cocktail with Malibu. For me, the spiciness of the tequila came through. Will make this one again.

Used Blue Curacao Liqueur instead of the syrup. Looked great, tasted great.
(Sweet Lady No. 2)
Thanks for bringing this to my attention. The recipe should have said blue curacao rather than syrup. Now fixed.
Is there a single-serving version of this? If so, I'm not easily finding it...
Hi Peter, the single serve recipe is called 'Manhattan (Sweet)' and should appear in search results if you search for 'Sweet Manhattan'.
Is there any particular reason it's recommended to stir after chilling instead of just adding the necessary dilution beforehand?

I like the theatre and ceremony of stirring even pre-batched cocktails. Helps make more special than just pouring a beer. If you'd prefer to batch with dilution, then add 195ml / 6.5oz of water to above recipe.

Great to compare to the Gin & It. At the risk of sounding obvious, this one is definitely a martini in flavour and style. I also went with a lemon twist, and a tiny spritz of orange bitters. 50/50 Punt e Mes and Carpano on this occasion. As the other DD’s commented, dangerously drinkable! Knocked it back by a third as it’s a school night, but immediately tempted to make another!

What a fantastic drink! I can't quite believe it's getting so little attention compared with the Gin & It, which it trumps so easily. I'll be using this to roadtest any new sweet vermouth that comes my way. I did switch in a twist of lemon, instead of the cherry - more in keeping with a proper grown-up and phenomenally dry, but balanced, cocktail, I felt. As John Hart says, dangerously smooth - in a VERY good way!
Caorunn and Carpano Classico, dangerously smooth
Oh I like it. It’s citrus season in California and Mexico, and experimenting with different oranges, tangerines, Buddha’s hands, — it all tastes GREAT. The fresh juice is everything

I think I like it with less drambuie.
Too sweet otherwise.
Champers Pats? No darling, I must have a Sweetie Darling!
Very smooth flavour combination. Great for a brunch or a light afternoon cocktail.

Like others below, I cut the Suze to 3/4. I also increased the kirsch to 1 1/4 and replaced the sugar rim with 1/3 simple syrup (you really need the bit of extra sweetness, I think). All in all an excellent drink, leading off with mild cherry before transitioning to herbal notes, and finishing off with mild gentian bitterness.

I never comment but this is absolutely phenomenal. Admittedly I can't taste the Kirsch but my bottle of G. Miclo has been open a long time. This is no bad thing however, as when it was fresh I really didn't like it! Don't know why but I prefer a great many cocktails on the rocks (like here) rather than up.

This is yummy! I do recommend cutting back the gentian liquor ( I used aveze) and scaled it down a bit to fit more nicely in a highball glass.

so 3/4, 1/2, 3/4, 1/2
With the gentian equal parts to the other spirits you lose parts of the chartreuse and most of the cherry notes from the kirsch
Just a hair too sweet for me, but the blackberries added a fun little component. If you want a fresh cocktail that's not too fruity and still full bodied, this one's for you :)

Loved this. Taking the gimlet cue a bit further used a split of lime cordial (per Morgenthaler) in lieu of simple and fresh lime juice, which gave it a slightly more grippy character. Fantastic for a hot afternoon doing nothing.
Definitely be generous with the angostura float
Made a pair of these last night. It's a great post-dinner drink, perhaps even a 'dessert daiquiri'. The banana liqueur and the orange juice seems to add some welcome viscosity.
Ok how did you get that color? Mine looks like some premixed MaiTai from the store
Our present image was supplied by Bacardi. I've just made and mine is also not nearly so dark red.
Good drink sticking to the recipe, but I also muddled some pomegranate seeds because I had them as an experiment. Nice addition as well...

Loved this. It does not have a much of a bitter hint at the end of sip. Will admit that we ran out of Reposado tequila so we did 1 oz Reposado and 1/2 Anejo. It was wonderful. Nice flavour of the tequila and the coolness of the lime.
This is a great drink, better than a G&T for me. I prefer the Fever Tree Light when I make it. Best just given to people because if you describe it, they'll turn their nose up.
Quite a refreshing drink.

I didn't have cranberry on hand, so I subbed with a 3:2 blend of homemade grenadine-to-lime, and I think it came out close enough. The honey is rather prominent. My take here resulted in a sort of richer version of a Scofflaw maybe? Decent swill, nonetheless. (28 Sep 2022, 10:25a)

Balanced and more complex than you’d expect. Don’t be put off by the honey syrup its easy to make in the microwave - 15ml of honey (1 tbsp) plus 5 ml (1 tsp) water in something like an egg cup - about 30s but keep an eye on it

Cranberry juice is a little ambiguous. Most would interpret it as cranberry juice cocktail with water and sugar added to make it drinkable. We used pure cranberry juice and it wasn’t too sweet. Could have even used a tad more Falernum.
We used Eager Cranberry Juice but Ocean Spray would also work.
Too sweet for me. Needs more citrus to balance. Grapefruit is not enough
Agreed. Hence, not just 5ml honey water syrup.
I juiced Orangegold oranges for this recipe. It's surprisingly fruity despite the small liqueur quantities. Beautifully balanced and very tasty.
I used a cheap orange juice and instantly regretted it, requires a good one for sure!

This does, as advertised, taste faintly almond-ish. Mostly it tastes quite sweet. Oranges vary widely; if you have standard navel or cara cara oranges, a splash of lemon juice might help bring the whole thing to life. Even without it, it's a tasty cocktail.
Just one word: wow!

I normally make this with Roku and it’s great, but tonight I made it with Ukiyo blossom gin and it really ups the floral aspect. Not everyone’s cup of tea but if you like that sort of thing, I recommend giving it a try.

Five plus for me. Not sure why, but this combination of flavours does it for me without fail. Used crème de violette as no parfait amour, and remaining true to the history. Garnished with homemade morello cherries steeped in sugar syrup, Luxardo maraschino liqueur and brandy… yum!!

I think the genius of this cocktail lies in the balance of sweet (liqueur) sour (lemon) that provides a foil to the gin’s botanical flavours, particularly the cardamom seed in the case of tanqueray 10.
Perfect blend of herbal and floral. Has just a hint of sweet and the parfait amour add jus the right colour. The lemon twist add the hint of citrus smell as you sip. Wonderful.

Very much enjoyed this. Have had a bottle of Parfait Amour gathering dust for a couple of years, which I bought before I knew I could source Creme de Violette here in Singapore. Having randomly read the Difford's review of the former (I was on a Bols trawl, I struck upon this cocktail. Surprising to see how few cocktails there are on the site with Parfait Amour, really. Maybe it's due a renaissance?

Variation: One website calls the Takumi : 45 mL Tanqueray No. TEN gin
15 mL Giffard Maraschino Liqueur
1 Barspoon Marie Brizard Parfait Amour
10 mL Fresh Lemon Juice
so I tried it, substituting Tanqueray No 10 +grapefruit and rosemary. This yielded a beautifully balanced cocktail; color like Hanalei fog. Yet I am NOT an Aviator fan; I once said an Aviator tastes like sugar in the gas tank. Tomorrow I'll mix the Gifford's above w available Kalimansi (not Japanese lime).

Outstanding nightcap. Originally made per the recipe, and used Johnnie Walker Black. Decided to do a misting of absinthe to the top of the drink and it took it to another level. Some of the smoky of the Scotch Whisky was softened and the other flavours of the Whisky came to the forefront along with the herbals. Perfect.
A wonderful drink. The touch of absinthe really elevates the whole thing.
Excellent with Jonnie Walker Black and Cocchi Storico.
“Rob-Bob” may not be as poetic but it’s certainly a shorter name for the love child of a Rob Roy + Bobby Burns

I agree. This is a very delightful cocktail. Very citrus tasting, but with a slight hint of the rum. We used a light Barbados rum which is not as sweet as many of the other rums. A little on the tart side, but very refreshing.

Very likable drink, a definite four. Tanglefoot seems to have two meanings, it’s an insect repellant, and, in the US, an archaic word for “low-quality whiskey, especially home-brewed”. Which sort of connects to the prohibition in America, an association supported by the inclusion of Swedish punsch. There is, though, no history of this drink available here or elsewhere – or at least I have not been able to dig it up. Can anyone shed light on this?

Tanglefoot in the US actually was a name put onto any cheap liquor prior and during prohibition. As these two ingredients can be made by a bootlegger, I assume the name. Here is a link to an article on prohibition and they do mention tanglefoot as cheap liquor. https://www.legendsofamerica.com/ah-prohibitionspeakeasy/
Inthis form makes a fabulous brunch cocktail as in previous comment. If you’re looking for a pre dinner cocktail then reduce the grapefruit to 30ml and add a dash of grapefruit bitters

Works well as the revised and convenient three-ingredient cocktail. Refreshing and fruity without being sweet. Some may prefer optional sugar syrup to taste. Definitely one (or three) for a hot summer day, especially if flights to somewhere exotic and tropical cannot be relied upon...!
Great brunch cocktail. Not too sweet and very refreshing. Had it for my 70th Birthday brunch.

Both my daughters like a Porn Star Martini and during lockdown we couldn't get lemons and limes, but could get grapefruit so we decided to try this cocktail. My daughters enjoy this more than me and would probably score this a bit higher. I found it a fraction too sweet for my taste and we did try without the sugar syrup, but, as we found out, the sugar syrup is needed to balance the "bitterness" of the grapefruit, not the sourness.

It's 17 years since I last tried this cocktail and in that time glasses and serves have much reduced in scale. Hence, I scaled this drink back and while doing so I've also rebalanced to remove the sugar syrup. Happily, it's now a 3-ingredient cocktail and hopefully also better balanced.
Second time around I had to add a heart to the five stars!

I only had 15% triple sec, so I substituted 40% Cointreau. Delicious nevertheless! This seems very similar to the Dubliner and James Joyce cocktails -- they are all riffs on a Manhattan, but with orange liqueur substituted for some of the vermouth, and perhaps some extra aromatics.

Very nice. Orange and whiskey work well together. The single dashes of orange and angostura bitters was perfect. I used Pierre Ferrand’s dry Curaçao but it was still sweet enough. The vermouth and grenadine worked well.
This is so smooth and a outstanding aperitif. Not too sweet, but you can taste all the different flavours in the cocktail. Great colour. Would do again.

Glad I tried this. Excellent long drink (it grew on me). Lacking apples to slice, I lightly dusted the surface with cinnamon. Can only wonder how much better better this could be with authentic Polish bison grass vodka as the U.S. version contains no coumarin, the essential flavor component in sweet grass!
Was out of limes so used lemon. I liked it better! I'm thinking lemon pairs better with apples than lime does.
Agreed Chris. Also, thanks to comment by Ignacy, I now know that lemon juice is the correct Polish traditional serve.

Traditionally in Poland this cocktail is build in the glass (no shaker) putting in order Zubrowka, apple juice and lemon juice without even stirring. It is the Polish equivalent of gin and tonic. I tried the shaker version but it doesn't taste the same. It is served with cinnamon powder and a piece of apple as a garnish.

For the record, tatanka is a rift of a cocktail called Szarlotka (Apple pie) made only with zubrowka and apple juice.
It was a good experiment to see how the method of preparation changes the taste of the cocktail. The shaker version exacerbates the citrus tones significantly.
Many thanks, Ignacy. I've amended to be stirred in glass rather than shaken. I'll reshoot to also correct the garnish.
Found the amount of apple juice overpowering but cannot wait to try in apple season with russets.
I didn’t have lime juice the first time around, but second time with lime juice certainly elevates this. Tastes less alcoholic than it is. Delicious.
Great pre-dinner aperitif. I didn’t have absinthe which I think it must need. Not overly dry but not sweet either. I like it.
"Brewed cold" does it mean brewed then chilled or brewed in cold water? and how would one do the latter?
"Brewed" was confusing so I have removed. Brew tea in boiling water, remove tea bag/strain after 4-5 mins, and leave to cool.
I made it with fresh lemon juice & sprite in place of lemonade & sugar syrup. Wow! It's very refreshing. It made me crave for some tacos or burritos!
Instead of the cream I add some coconut dairy free yoghurt. Want to add some of the M&S coconut ice cream as well to really experiment with the recipe.
My kids loved this drink. There was a little leftover after I divvied out their drinks so I added a mix of rums, lime juice, more pineapple juice, and falernum to drink the rest myself.
Pineapple coconut milkshake!
Hmm. I've had the original with Abano & really like it. I'll have to try this version now. Nice!

So, this is *not* one of those “better than the sum of its parts” cocktails.

It’s just…meh.

Had this as an after-dinner cocktail. Was perfect. Loved the hint of hazelnut and the mixture of the other ingredients. Slightly sweet, but perfect after a good dinner. Would also be great as a later evening cocktail.
Lost in translation…

I came across this recipe, and it's the same as my personal martini recipe, except that I use a different dry vermouth and I make a smaller 45 ml/22.5 ml cocktail. Grapefruit bitters make a huge difference in this drink. I've used orange bitters, of course, and I've tried lemon bitters, but grapefruit bitters provide a much smoother, more drinkable result.
My kind of martini. Enjoyed it very much.

Refreshing with the subtle tang of gragefruit adding an exciting and original dimension to a wet Martini. In the absence of Rutte, I used Plymouth Gin which seems to work well in Martinis, as an alternative.
Excellent martini. The grapefruit bitters add an interesting touch. Wet, but the flavour of the gin shines. Love it.

I didn't see this Negroni riff called for Luxardo/Aperol instead of Campari. It is quite excellent with Campari, though I imagine much less sweet. This worked for us with excellent quality overproof blanco tequila - worth a try if you have good tequila!
Nice! Love it with tequila. Nice change from gin Negroni or bourbon boulevardier.
Perhaps a little sweet made as stated. We substituted a Rouge vermouth and voila! much more to our liking. With or without modification, a very niiiicccceee Negroni rif.
With a little adjustment: 5ml of Oleo Saccharum of Bitter Orange peel extra. Great!

Asked the bartenders at The Booking Office in Kings Cross to make me one of these last night. (I think they used the classic equal parts Alexander recipe as they didn't have a Difford's Guide handy... but added a little bit more white creme de cacao after tasting it.) More to the point, though, both the bartenders and they were surprised just how good this turned out. Will definitely make again.
There’s egg white in the list of ingredients, so wondering if DRY SHAKING should be added to the instructions.
Would benefit from a dry shake. I've added above.
Very refreshing and flavourful. Always have an issue with cocktails which "top off" as I find glasses vary in volume. We used a 10 oz glass and it was perfect. Drinks very easily.
Perfect for an 80° humid summer day
I prefer without the soda
Very refreshing for hot summer ! I love it
I made this with Lemon Schweppes and with 2 cl of rich sugar syrup
Very refreshing. Had with fish tacos and it was great. Would be great on a hot afternoon with snacks.
I used G4 High Proof, Contratto Bianco, orange bitters, and lemon twist. Changed the ratio to 3:1. It was quite good, but can't top a gin martini.

Editorial note: we think the "How to make" should read "...into ice-chilled glass.", not "...ice-filled". This is one of two recipes that has persuaded us that the Martini can indeed be a great cocktail.

Been playing with this one for a few months now. RT below hits the nail on the head; the tequila will dictate the outcome. Use Siete Leguas, Lalo or an equivalent. Try a Reposado. I have found the Italian Martini & Rossi to be the best match (over Dolin, my fav gin vermouth) but dial it down to 3:1. Bitters optional, but absolutely worth playing with. Orange, lemon or grapefruit are all good choices. This is absolutely the best summertime, pool-side Martini I've ever had (I've had a few).
Made with Altos Plato and Martini Bianco, was easy drinking but nothing special.

Much better with mezcal, but I may be a mezcal tragic.

Also works very well with unaged grappa and lemon, although I haven’t tried the dry vermouth version of the grappatini to compare.

The impression this makes will vary enormously depending on the tequila used. With tequila Ocho it was sublime, with Sauza "Hornitos" it was good but not exciting. I recommend Dolin Blanc, as I don't think tequila stands up to the funkier Italian biancos. It's the same story with gin martinis.

Loved this - I made it with Boker's Bitters in the absence of Margarita Bitters, which worked just finr. A word of warning - strain it into an ice-filled standard coupe as advised and it wont fit! I just slurped and topped it up - all good.
First taste was amazing but the more I drunk the more the taste of Cinzano Bianco overwhelmed the tequila. Ultimately a disappointment.
Is this a new 5+? Unless I’ve missed it!!
Hi Lee. I'm not aware of my making a recent addition, certainly not in the last few months, so one you may have missed. Hopefully, you have the ingredients to hand and find it worthy of the rating.

It's not bad (it's quite good) but it is very weird. It's very minty in the "I'm expecting at the very least chocolate, if not cream" way but then you get agave and lime and tartness. It is very green though.
A minty margarita of sorts! Right up my alley, but I can see how others would not enjoy.

No es mi gusto. Although Jimador Reposado is my preferred Tequila I still could not finish this drink. And I did not have Gifford Peppermint, I had Phillips. (Sorry Liz, 3 of 8 of Her Maj’s Difford cocktails for the Jubilee)

I've got vodka down; that was easy. Have a basic understanding and variety of whiskeys. I understand gin. My next stop is exploring tequilas. I used silver as that is all I have on hand. It's an interesting concoction. Not sure I will make it again, but here's to Atticus; he was a stand up guy.

Should you happen to have an ironic bottle of creme de menthe knocking around (at what stage can you describe it as ‘vintage’?) then you could do a lot worse than this. Looks like mouthwash tastes lush.
Definitely an after dinner drink. It tastes super sweet actually, sort of like a 'meh' Reposado Julep. A bit strange, in spite of the modest agave syrup content.

One of the few cocktails I have not liked. Found it way too sweet and without flavour. Mint was lost and a waste of good tequila. Did add a splash of lime to lessen the sweetness, but still found it just "ok."
It is simple, but it's great
this could never fail.

Okay, I get that this is a Tommy's Margarita + egg white - and it's balanced, because the Tommy's is delicious. But...something just isn't right with tequila and egg white. You sip it and you get that agave sour tang and then it's all silky and smooth and it's really quite odd. It's kind of unsettling.
Have had this with limoncello and lemon juice and it was amazing
Thanks, Lou. I'll be sure to try.

Why sugar syrup and not agave syrup?
Enhance with margarita/lavender bitter
Indeed, why not? I've amended the recipe above accordingly. I've also changed to be served straight-up rather than on-the-rocks. (I'll re-photo ASAP.)
this one is really yummy. With the egg white, it's like a new experience matching with tequila. I tried with agave reposado and with blanco, both are good in my opinion

This was nice. Not memorable. Recipe reminded me of the traditional rum punch without the flavours the rum adds. While you can taste the tequila, it seems to be overwhelmed by the other ingredients. After tasting, we did do a 1/3 oz float of anejo tequila on the top and it added more tequila taste. Still it was good; not great.

wasn't sure exactly what "7 spoons" should be, but google told me a bar spoon is 5ml, so i used 35ml honey. the resulting drink had a very strong, sweet honey taste - too much for me. not sure if i did this one right but it was still pretty good
Thanks for bringing this to my attention. I've reworked the recipe above to use honey syrup.

I "made up" a drink like this when I was a bartender in Tokyo with no idea what I was doing. Mine was a highball that added Zubrowka and soda. For how young I was, I think it was pretty sophisticated.
I found it improved drastically after adding a few drops of saline solution.
Saline is a great call. I've added above.
Blimey! That's a taste. Not sure if I particularly like this, but I'll persevere!

Really lovely. Not sure how much lime juice I put in (half a lime, but the scale stayed a 0.0oz) but it's the perfect blend of fruitiness on the tongue and bitterness on the nose. Rubbed some lime on the rim for an extra touch of tartness and it was delightfully classy and semi-sweet.

I like up to a point Campari but this one looked a bit daunting so I tried a version by Richard Godwin which used 25ml of both Campari and Lime juice, 10 of Cassis but added 25 of Vodka. It was very nice. A touch tart, bitter but with just a hint of fruit. Possibly should be called a different name but I do not know when ‘adapted’ goes too far…
I think it's ok to very the proportions (I'll experiment) but adding vodka turns this into a different cocktail that requires renaming. As you say, "goes too far..."
Nice mix between bitter and sweet
Difford, when i click on Victors link on the history section im taken to a forbiden error on site .. FYI maybe link to trader vics page ?
Thanks for bringing this to my attention. Now fixed.
Great drink. Homemade falernum and skip the bitters (not needed).

Love this. It definitely needs to the Jamaican rum to get the correct amount of funk needed. However, you would need to like the Jamaican funk. If not, I sure you could make this with any other rum and it would be enjoyable. Nicely dry.
I used gold Puerto Rican rum and Demerara rum. For a drink so boozey this was surprisingly mellow and pleasant. One of my favourites
This drink shouldn't work, but it somehow does. Perhaps I'd call this drink a "diet zombie".

Bloody hell. How is this drink so smooth and easy to down? Whether it's the proportions or the bourbon (Makers Mark I used), it takes away even more of that edge from a regular Iced Tea. Super smooth drink
Omit the simple syrup. I used 1/4 sour mix and 1/4 margarita mix instead of lime and lemon juice. A terrific summer sipper for Southern afternoons in South Carolina.

I made this with Dolin dry, and I was pretty disappointed. It starts nicely enough, with a sort of slightly herbal whiskey note, but I found the finish to be almost unpleasant. It resolved in a bitterness that distracted from, rather than added to, the overall experience. I will stick to a Brown Derby next time I'm in the mood for a whiskey and grapefruit combo.

Wasn't what I was expecting. Interestingly enough, this cocktail tastes like a light bodied crisp white wine, very refreshing. The vermouth takes the lead here, and I suppose in Texas fashion, whips the whiskey into shape
Nice. The basil comes through first and the red pepper is in the aftertaste. I added a basil leaf to the garnish. I think the green contrasts nicely with the pepper.
Sounds delicious!! Question: is the coconut water the neutral/clear variant? Or does it need to have the sweet coconutty flavour?
Clear coconut water such as Vita Coco Natural Coconut Water.

Thanks for pointing out. "Fresh" and "sprig" should have been inputted as "shot" when I uploaded to our CMS. Now fixed. It's been over a decade since I last made this cocktail, I need to remember to try again when I have red pepper to hand.
Although contemporary, very much in the vintage mode: strong, unapologetic flavours. Rich, fruity and spirituous.
Ingredients list says Dolin Rouge but Review says Vermouth di Torino (assume Cocchi)... not sure which is preferred here?
Looks like im having the same issue. Both vermouths are in my added ingredients.
I suspect only saying Dolin Rouge for you as you have this in Your Ingredients as your preferred Rooso vermouth.
The Froupe's big brother, with half the vermouth and bitters, and twice the Benedictine. The jury is out on which I prefer, and further playing with proportions is needed.
Much better than the Froupe. Better showcase for all the ingredients... The Boker's will stand out if you apply with a heavy hand.

First cocktail I made with a newly acquired bottle of Biker's Bitters. I'm not certain how strong the flavor of the bitters are specifically, but this is an absolutely lovely cocktail. I will be making this again!
Well spotted, the two cocktails are really only separated by the amount of vermouth. I've added a link to Froupe above. Thanks for pointing out.
As a south-east London boy myself, I'll certainly be trying this sometime soon. It does, however, look suspiciously like the more traditional Froupe Cocktail...
Love this - my favourite Harvard riff. It's a shame it doesn't show up when you search on Rosso Vermouth, though
Thanks for letting me know. This should now show when you search rosso vermouth.
Used black tot rum as it was the only thing to hand, but very nice indeed

Beautiful and smooth evening sipper. Everything works perfectly. A hint of sweetness, but then the bitter. The herbal of the sherry and the rich flavours of the rum. I used 1/2 overproof gold rum and an 8 year old gold. Went perfectly watching a concert of Elgar.
Ran out of Fino, so I tried it with dry vermouth instead - turned out great!

Lovely sipper that perfectly strikes a balance between rich sweet ness and nutty sherry minerality. Collour and flavour are incredibly pleasurable. Year round sipper as the ice helps cut the richness.
Any 2 of these ingredients? Sure. Any 3? Eeesh. All 4? Absolute madness. But it works, and it is downright delicious.
Tastes like mint humbugs.
Very good. Like an improved Rob Roy with the addition of maraschino and absinthe.

Perfect for an evening sipper or nightcap. Loved the mixture of flavours and the lovely hint of absinthe. Originally I thought it was a bit sweet, but the cocktail softens and blends together as it warms up. A keeper.
This one is a keeper, I've been coming back to it often. I personally like it even better with ¾ oz. sweet vermouth.
Great with absinthe! Lovely sweet, cherry, honey, vanilla, and anise. Boozy, spicy, and a hint sweet. Just how I like it.

Pleasant, but a bit too absinthe forward (and I love absinthe). Just missed tasting more of the scotch and maraschino.
Nice mouthfeel though and the cherry was a nice treat at the end.
Hi David. I've just revisited The Ansonia and thanks to your comment, I've cut the absinthe in half and now a much better cocktail. Less is more!
Found the lime a little too predominant so would reduce it next time. All in all, quite a nice and very drinkable autumn cocktail.

The Lime and Apple juice make for a nice complex interplay without adding another Liqueur. Great cocktail to balance out a heavy dish without fighting for attention. On the third go-round I ended up with 2/3 oz of St. Germain and 1 1/2 oz of bourbon for a better balance with the food. (Not quite so boozy) The Mrs. liked it with a little splash of soda water. It’s a keeper for us.
Many thanks. I tried your version of this cocktail and changed the recipe accordingly.
For those a bit leary of creme de menthe, as we are, Acqua Bianca works a treat.
One might even want to go as far as 15ml with the Acqua Bianca. Cheers.
Absolutely fine with green crème de menthe if that’s what you have

I think the comparison with lemonade and toothpaste below is unfair! I made this with Plymouth Gin, Volare White Crème de Menthe and my niece's homemade Sloe Gin which, after a good 4+ year sitting has acquired a very slightly viscous consistency and depth of flavour. The mint liqueur adds a satisfying background 'sting' and coolness. Important not to use too much of it!
Isn't this basically the same recipe as "Astor Punch" on page 106 of Jacques Straub's 1913 Manual of Mixed Drinks?
Thanks, Henry. It is indeed. I've added Staub's recipe above.
I made this last night with Tempus Fugit creme de menthe and the some very nice home made sloe gin. Delicious.

Wow! No... Again, I'm probably using bad brands (De Kuyper creme de menthe, Gordon's, Hayman's Sloe Gin), but this tasted like Sprite and toothpaste (more the latter)... Clearly, I need to regroup and get quality products. Yuck. (5 Feb 2022, 5:10p)

I used giffards creme de menthe, homemade sloe gin and Bombay sapphire.

I haven’t had a good time with de kuyper at all. The only one that I liked was their blue curaçao. But that’s just because it’s supposed to be artificial and the flavour is just orange.

I used Gordon’s as the base for the homemade sloe gin, but for a drinking gin, you wanna bump up the quality. If you don’t like it in a gin and tonic, you won’t like it in a cocktail.
Delicious. On second try I doubled the violettes but not the absinthe - the absinthe is so overpowering that it’s more balanced (to my taste) that way.

I’m surprised there isn’t a named martini variation with equal parts vermouth and violette (but no absinthe). Basically a perfect 3:1 martini but with cdv in place of sweet vermouth. I’m drinking one now and it’s delicious. (I also added some rosemary-lavender bitters).

If you already have a 3:1 gin/vermouth combo in the freezer ready to go for your instant martini, then this is a nice twist and, as Simon said, double the creme de violette (and maybe the absinthe) for the shaken version and then it has a distinct violet hue (unlike that photo Simon?)
Photo is of the 1.25ml stirred version.

Following Jacqueline Kirk's, we first tried as written and then upped the Creme de Violette by another 3 dashes. It enhanced the flavour of the overall cocktail for us and seemed to make the taste a bit more tame.

Even though this cocktail works out well, I have a feeling that the "3 Dashes Crème de Violette" is a typesetting error, and that line should have been in the next cocktail in the book, the Aviation, from whence it is missing.

Sorry, I think you misunderstand me. The typo is not here in your guide, but in Craddock's 1930 Savoy Cocktail Book. Ensslin's Recipes for Mixed Drinks has the Crème de Violette in the Aviation, and the Savoy plagiarizes heavily from Ensslin's book.

The above 3 dashes creme de violette are correct. We have two versions of the Aviation, one with The Savoy spec (which as per the book omits creme de violette) and my own version which does include creme de violette.
Hi, just guessing here - but did it used to be 1/4 ounce and was upped to 1/2 oz for the liqueur and absinthe? I was a bit caught off by the 1/24 oz....
Got it! Thank you.
Hi Jamie. 1/24oz is 1.25ml or 1/4 of a barspoon. This is the smallest measure on our Easy Jigger shown in both oz and ml.
This is definitely a cocktail that suffers because I need to up my vermouth game. I like the concept, but when I make it with my cheap extra dry it doesn't quite work.
An excellent dry violette cocktail, this one will be in my regular rotation now for sure. I even added a touch more violette but I'm crazy about it.
Made it exactly as written and thought it was too sweet. 1 or 1/2 tsp of simple syrup should be adequate. Smooth, balanced and rather subtle. Opens up nicely after the pour.
Not unpleasant but the coffee overwhelmed the other ingredients. Maybe my espresso is too strong (I don't do cold brew)
not a bad way to dress up some gos, id prefer some more kick to it though

I love anything with black strap rum. This has a great smoothness. Don't go overboard on shaking because the pineapple juice will aerate more than other citrus and cause a foam situation that might make the cocktail too much liquid for the glass. I also recommend a Collins class for that very reason.
Pineapple sweetness smoothes out the ginger punch. Good for those who might find a Dark & Stormy a bit too intense.

I made it with maple syrup instead of sugar and added the cinnamon into the shaker with rest of the ingredients.
Wonderful, autumnal drink, reminiscent of an apple-cinnamon cookie.

I've opted for a bit of ruby port topping the cream, as I've seen in I think several other sours, but I might be mistaken; i.e., I like it, but it is at your own risk to use it instead of the topping of cinnamon powder
Liked this a lot. As I didn’t have saline solution, I used smoked salt which worked wonderfully with the bourbon.
Shaking with the apple cider inside the shaker is not a problem?
It's apple juice, not cider. Not a problem to shake with apple juice.

In my haste to try this drink I forgot to dust with cinnamon. Oh well!
Still tasted absolutely delicious.

cocktail: The Bird Is The Word No. 2

comments.comment: This is my second Grappa cocktail…. I shall always have a bottle of Grappa next to Green Chartreuse…..love it.

As a big Last Word fan I approached this cocktail with some trepidation. It was great! It's still a Last Word with the vegetal character of the grappa really shining through in a good way.

Be careful with the chocolate bitters. It must remain subtle, barely discernible, but it adds a unique twist to the drink in the right amount.

Interesting, posted this in a cocktail community, with DG and the Salon 39 as reference and someone asked if it was a small riff on the "Mistaken By Strangers" from Misty Kalkofen from Boston, Brick & Mortar Bar. Same drink, same ratio, just without the bitters. Served in a rock glass, but also without ice.
And it's a really nice one btw, first 1-2 sips I wasn't sure since the flavour combination is quite unique but really liked it after that.
Many thanks, Mikael. I've amended the page accordingly.

Hi Simon & Robin,

This cocktail was created by myself and my team back in 2009 or 2010 when I was a bar manager at Salon 39.
This is a wonderful cocktail. The Grappa flavour is pronounced but not overpowering. Just the right amount of sweetness. The herbal, chocolate kick is perfect.

Definitely on the right page! A tasty Last Word riff. A quality Grappa (Domes Ruche) helps! Though finding the right balance of chocolate bitters is an ongoing experiment. Currently trying out Bittered Sling Malagasey bitters; according to their packaging a dash is 10 drops which seems excessive but my standard 4 drops did not add anything to the party,,, I will eventually bite the bullet and invest in Bob's!
Your recent email listed the recipe as Tequila based.
"Grappa-based"???
The page should have directed to the tequila-based "Bird Is The Word No.1". Now fixed. Thanks for bringing to my attention.
Try with dry gin instead
Amazing drink for the simplicity of the spec!

Used Teeling (“Spirit of Dublin”) rum-cask finish whiskey, Abecassis “Reve Bleu” XO cognac to stand up to the double dose of whiskey, Dolin rouge vermouth (not overly rich). Upped Benedictine to 1/4 oz (Difford specifies 1/3 oz for the Vieux Carre’ with just 3/4 oz of whiskey). Angostura and Bitter Truth Creole bitters. Didn’t understand the lime twist so garnished with dried blood orange wheel in an old-fashioned with a large ice cube. Great choice for UNESCO Literacy Day. Slainte mhaith!

Great for aperitif or after dinner. Works well straight up and the flavours are enhanced. Totally surprised by this one, as I usually find cocktails with Benedictine can be sweet. Not this one perfect balance.
Wow! I really like Godfather, but didn't think that Bourbon would make that much a difference. I was wrong. Only had Maker's Mark at home but next time I'll try with a different one!
Adapted slightly with 2oz bourbon, 3/4 oz amaretto, 1/4 oz luxardo maraschino. It was really delicious! After a hard day at work I’m calling this “Screw the Boss” ;)
Excellent adaptation! Since there was Luxardo Maraschino in the cocktail, it absolutely needed a Luxardo Maraschino cherry as a garnish!
Instead of bourbon, decided to use a double barrel American Whiskey with the final aging in port casks. It was great. Very smooth with the hints of almond. Great as a night cap.

I am not a big fan of mezcal as I find to too smoky. However, I did enjoy this cocktail. Yes, it has the smoky taste, but if you let the cocktail rest the smoky taste goes into the background. It is still there, but not overwhelming. Really enjoyed.
I'll be alternating between this and the Perfectly Straight Blood and Sand. Once again thanks Simon.

I thought this was a good twist on the Blood & Sand, though truthfully I'd usually rather drink a Blood & Sand than this. The flavors are really well balanced though, you can taste the agave spirits without any edge, but my indifference towards tequila prevents me from appreciating that balance too much. I think this would actually be fantastic in a highball though, it hits that boozy + refreshing + slightly sweet spot that benefits from some crisp carbonation. Will report back after I try it.
I know exactly what Mr Broad meant. The first thought that came to my mind was “menacing”. I think it’s the mezcal underlying everything else. Delicious, but menacing.
Yup, dark alleys can be menacing but a lot of fun stuff can go on down a dark alley!
A nice strawberry liqueur is a great addition to this drink.
What you suggest as an appropriate liqueur to match with gin? A sweet vermouth?
Any of the many orange liqueurs work well but I particularly like orange curacao. Elderflower is another safe bet.

I quite like this. Have made it twice with that new bottle of damson (gin) liqueur as it's the only recipe I have all the ingredients for... albeit with a substitution or two. Genepy for the Chartreuse and Torres 10 for the Cognac. Guess that makes it more of a Strapping Spaniard than a Burly Frenchman. Liked how the aromatic flavors of the Absinthe, Damson, and lemon zest hovered over the heavier elements.
Has potential but over-complicated.

First off, first time, over dilution just killed this for me. Second, my opinion is skewed and biased from using (first, gin - but also) the very distinct Barr Hill honey (a raw honey might yield similar results for you). Properly, delicately diluted, this is amazing. Give it to me all day. Gin tops white rum with lime. I can't deny.
Ford's and Nate's Organic raw honey made a fine swill, but not an eye-popping, 5-star madness like with the Barr Hill.
Original recipe for The Business is 3/4 oz honey syrup.
Many thanks, Georgette. I've added the original recipe from Regarding Cocktails.
Gorgeous with homemade pear & honey syrup 🍐
More complex in taste than the bees knees

Also went with a botanical Gin (Botanist). Great combination of flavors. The honey is very prevalent on the nose, but it gets a little bit lost in the palate. Great citrus overtones with a nice gin finish.

Great mixture of ingredients. Simple and refreshing. Gin give some nice herbal tones with the honey syrup. Great as designed.
However, since we saw this basically as a daiquiri made with gin. After tasting, we added the equivalent of 4 drops of Difford's Diaquiri Bitters. Pulled the flavours to a new level. Either way it is great.
Personally I prefer this over a Bee's Knees, & this recipe made with Esme botanical New-Age Gin is a perfect combination!
And also with Palo Tunel and 2 extra dashes of orange bitters instead of Picon or China China
Very, very nice with a Picon Amer instead of Bigallet.
Oh. That's very kind. Thank you, Simon.

I successfully ‘threw’ the cocktail - and not all over my kitchen floor - Yipeee!! I also had a lot of ‘same as but different’ subs, heering is always too sweet for me so cut it in half, and added Cynar, no Punt so Antica as suggested below. So, I guess not really same as lol. But what counts - It is very tasty! And I’ll make it again.

I didn't have Punt e Mes so I used Antica Formula. But it tasted a bit sweet, so I added 5 ml of Cynar and it worked out fine. More than fine. But maybe still a bit sweet. Such a change would probably need a more careful rebalancing, maybe cutting a bit of cherry Heering. Anyway, a great cocktail, four and a half stars.
the ingredients listed are far different than what video contains?
As we say above, this recipe is "adapted" from the original by Georgia (in the video). We've adapted the recipe to use ingredients more generally available around the world.

Perfect after dinner or evening cocktail. Did not taste the maple shrub much, but felt it calmed the flavours coming from the Fernet and sweetness from the Apricot.
Into my 4th year of serious cocktail making, I would agree that you must use good ingredients even for those cocktails with many tastes.
Not saying to use the top shelf, but a good middle liquor. The better you can afford the more reward you will have.

Interesting blend of flavors. The shrub hits hardest at first, but the Fernet does somehow poke through. By the second sip, the Cognac (used lousy Godet) and apricot have emerged. Much here to spark one's interest and imagination... Incidentally, I love drinks which feature ingredients I'm trying to purge (running low) and the first 3 fit that bill. Great find! (25 Jun 2022, 12:24p)

I gave this a 5 with 1738 cognac. I gave it 3.5 with some other cognac which I don't remember. Cognac based drinks to me are those that are most dependent on which exact base spirit you use to determine whether or not it will be a nice cocktail or a terrible cocktail!

Fascinating cocktail. Deliciously dry and perfectly balanced. I only had a little muscovado syrup left, so topped it up with a mill or two of Luxardo. Perfect balance of the ingredients and charmingly dry. The mole bitters work beautifully with the whiskers to create a malty kind of flavour. Would definitely have again.

This is a fantastic Old Fashioned riff. I would say the Conference and Oaxacan Old Fashioned from Death and Co, as well as Jamie Boudreau's Cubed Old Fashioned, are probably my top 3 Old Fashioned recipes out there.
Great for evening sipping or a nightcap.

A winner. Very pleased with this drink, which I prepared for the first time yesterday. Attractive hue, enticing scent, and a sophisticated, complex melange of flavors with, exactly as described, all in balance and none singing out of tune. I did not have the mole bitters and substituted with El Guapo Chicory Pecan.
Lovely, sophisticated cocktail that's very quick and easy to make. I'll adding it to my regular rotation.
Loved it- was a bit doubtful due to mixing rye & bourbon- will try a version with just one, but Calvo & Cognac the bitters & syrup make it sing! Cheers!

Pleasant, but basic. Exactly what you would expect from the three ingredients. Not an example of "greater than the sum of its parts" . Needs top quality ingredients. I used Glen Grant 10, and home made grenadine.

In lieu o pomegranate syrup or grenadine what are the thoughts on pomegranate molasses. I have used this in many recipes for my Kitchen … but reading up on things to do with scotch (my liquor or preference) i saw this and thought man molasses has some notes and tones that could really make this cocktail a banging good treat?
This strikes me as a drink which requires pinpoint balance - I went a little over, maybe 12ml of maraschino, and it was almost all I could taste

Coming back to it a year later, being very precise with my measurements...it's just really not good. At least now it's not just a maraschino bomb, but it's all around mediocre. Reminds me a lot of a martini, weirdly.
What a marvelous after-dinner drink. The herbal hints from the Benedictine along with the maraschino enhance the cognac. The prosecco enlivens the cocktail.
Way too bitter for me. Perhaps it should be blanc vermouth instead not dry?
Agreed! I've switched to bianco vermouth. Many thanks.

I feared the mild Speyburn would be overwhelmed here but it still shone through. Noilly and Suze play well together too.
I wish I had some rye whiskey to try too.
Surprisingly sublte. The ingredients work very nicely together.
Agreed. Never gone in for any riffs on the White Negroni as Suze just dominates. But this really works.
The Combier kümmel is excellent and stands up well to the tequila.
Had anyone else tried Golden Moon kummel, made in the US? They're isn't much kummel flavor on the cocktail so I'm wondering if my kummel is weaker treating than the traditional ones.
Sorry, Chris, I've not sampled Golden Moon Kummel. However, kummel is usually fairly intense in flavour.

We made the data back to back with the Azalea Margarita. I used Pomegranate Molasses for the Azalea. I forgot to clean the measure before I started making the Dante so we ended up with a "rinse" of pomegranate molasses in the Dante. The result more in depth flavor and a "suspended" molasses cloud in the Dante. Very cool.

Very delicate, a little buttery flavour with a finish in herb and lime tones. It is better to go for a better tequila here, such as the one suggested in the recipe, because the spicy basic Mexican vodka will dominate the whole cocktail.
Perfect cocktail. I used "Lehment Rostocker Doppelkümmel", a ideal product for cocktails. Nice caraway taste but not overwhelming and not too sweet, So the cocktail was perfectly balanced.

I to subbed agave for sugar syrup and Danish Akvavit for Kümmel. This is a good cocktail, not great, good. I like the Chartreuese and Akvavit with the tequila combo, the balance seems right. (4 of 8 of “Her Maj’s” Difford cocktails for the Jubilee. Don't think I will make it to the end today)

We loved this. Deliciously tangy and right up my tequila / chartreuse street. I subbed agave syrup, as usual, and Goldschlaeger for Kuemmel this time, but I will definitely order a bottle of Kuemmel to try out the original.

As I had just purchased some Kummel (Mentzandorf) I was drawn to this 5+ star cocktail only to realise I'd used the last of my Blanco Tequila making a Blood Orange Tequila (highly recommended), so what to use as an alternative. Mezcal seemed obvious but I had also recently purchased a couple of bottles of Raicilla and decided to experiment with that. I chose La Venenosa Sierra Volcanes de Jalisco- the inferno link seemed fated. Wow, just wow! I will have to go back to the original, but WOW!
I didn't have Raicilla to hand so tried your suggestion of mezcal. Delicious! so much so that I've added a Mezcal Dante page. Please see the link under "Vaiaratons" above. Many thanks, Matthew.
The peach works really well with the bourbon
It's like a gold rush with a hint of peach. Loved it.
Well spotted. I've added a link to Gold Rush above.
Great cocktail. Good balance between the bourbon and lemon. Did cut back a little on the honey syrup as I like my cocktails a bit drier.
Mer really enjoyed it.
Should you be following American politics then this is a lovely sipping companion. Just as nice straight up if it’s a bit chilly- a bit like a cold hot toddy
Many thanks for bringing to my attention. Can't believe I overlooked revisiting a cocktail with such a poignant name. I have amended recipe accordingly.
Rather liked it but used brandy and sake, not plum sake. Not at all sweet for me so added 20 ml of amaretto (for 2 people) and a squeeze of orange juice. It works for me.

This was delicious. Definitely bourbon-forward, but not super boozy. Not overly creamy, either. Everything else kind of blends together into a subtle flavorful blend that enhances the creamy bourbon with maybe the bitters being the most noticeable ingredient, but still subtly so . Made with a 50/50 mix of Wild Turkey 101 & 81 bourbon, Wild Turkey 101 Rye, Licor 43, Liber & Co Almond Orgeat, Disaronno, & Bittermens Xocolatl Mole bitters.
A really awesome dessert drink that more people should try. Its complex and creamy. Only the Rye is somehow lost and unnoticable.
Absolutely brilliant. Bright flavors with an ample "kick", and a creamy texture. It's definitely a special-occasion cocktail, but I'll have to indulge myself a little more often than that!
Surprisingly complex for an Alexander-type cocktail, but it all works really well. The chocolate bitters really help draw out the finish. Splendid.

One of the more interesting, sensory-evolving cocktails I've tried in awhile. Made just one, but I'm eager to try this again... Immediately wanted to tweak the specs until I let it pass over my palate a few times and mindfully observed the flavor changes. Used a bottled-in-bond bourbon in addition to a similar rye. Would prefer to have used a more quality amaretto... All of the drink's core components stand out. Really not necessary to adjust measurements. Kind of impressed. (22 Jan 2023, 2:07p)

OMG, this is outstanding. I was a bit dubious given the ingredients, but the final cocktail is amazing. The herbal of the absinthe and basil play well together and the rum adds a bit of punch.
It drinks easily. We made a triple for 2 cocktails in a coupe glass. Too good for the single recipe in the Nick and Nora.

I wish there was a little more volume in the final pour as the wash line is a bit low on my nick and nora, but I'm hesitant to adjust the recipe for as it stands is nicely balanced. Surprised at how nicely the absinthe plays in this.

I agree with Florian in that the apricot dominated the flavors. I also agree with Frederick that it could have used just a touch of sweetness added (like 1/6 oz/5 ml) for better balance, but I guess it is very dependent on the Cranberry juice you used.
Very good and refreshing cocktail. With a barspoon more cranberry juice (Ocean Spray) it was very well balanced and did not get sweet. Before, the apricot brandy dominated a bit.

This is great. Good variation of a margarita. We used cranberry juice only sweetened with sugar. If you use the unsweetened it will be too sour. I also stay way from cranberry juice which is sweetened with syrups. They get too sweet.

Perhaps my ingredients were a bit less sweet than they were supposed to be (I suspect that my cranberry drink lacked a certain amount of added sugar), but I feel like this drink needed a teaspoon or two of sugar to really mellow.
Loved the lipstick as a garnish, though. Obviously not much in the way of flavour, but I'm all about the old school pizzazz of a lipstick mark.

To us this lacked depth. So we added Rittenhouse Rye; first just 5ml and then 10ml. We think 5ml is enough. Makes it a different, slightly more fussy, drink and upsets the harmony of the proportions of the original recipe. But it worked better for us. You decide.

I've tried this once and didn't enjoy it as much as I'd hoped, but just tried it with Chichicapa Mezcal & Ocho plata Tequila and it was better the second time. Next time I'll change the ratios to 2/3 Mezcal, 2/3 Blanco Tequila, 1 bar spoon Campari, 1/3 Amaro Montenegro, 3/4oz Sweet V, & 1/2oz Dry V.
MiMamaMeDijo | Los Cabos | Pergote | Rivata ... not bad, mezcal and amaro seem to stand out a lot, satisfactorily bitter, doesnt blow my mind though

It's like chocolate cherry cordial with a hybrid mezcal/rhum thing. I subbed Cardamaro for the Montenegro... Tried it again with the original specs. Bitter-er, and more to my taste, but it lost the cordial sweets. (27 Jan 2024, 5:23p)

What a great aperitif. We are having Mexican food for dinner and was looking for a aperitif which would pair with the theme. This was perfect.
The smoky of the mezcal comes through nicely. The herbal and bitter flavours enhance the full cocktail.
Pleasant but perplexing. At my first attempt I accidentally omitted the Campari, but the prescribed formula wasn't dramatically different. Maybe less would be more...
Was intrigued by the list of ingredients, so had to try this cocktail. Blended nicely - like a new amaro (thinned out a bit with extra alcohol ??)
Great cocktail! Where does the name come from?
Many thanks for the insight. I've added this reference to the recipe above.
Sadly I have notes or further information on this cocktails origin. I guess it was made by or for Frank O'Hara, the New York poet.

I feel this drink is great any time of the day really. The maple syrup really makes it rich, but the lemon and cucumber refreshes it. The spirits are not as forward, but it is a great example that not every cocktail needs to be a glass of booze. I could still taste them too, the gin really comes with the cucumber, while the Cognac comes with the lemon and maple.
is not often i find myself not making changes to a cocktail, this one is just PERFECT ! top 10 for sure.

Hmm. More interesting than really delicious as far as I'm concerned. Certainly good flavors but I think I would rather have my cucumber and gin as a martini-style drink, and my cognac/maple combination as something else too.
Yum!

Thank you for the quick reply! By the way, it seems like a small amount of fluids (60ml) compared to most cocktails that are around 100-110ml. Or does the cucumber slice need to be thick enough to produce around 30ml of juice? Or do you shake this one longer than usual?
It is indeed a low volume cocktail and using specs above would be better served in a Nick & Nora glass.
Would the Merlet VSOP be a good cognac for this cocktail? Or would it be too fruity and mess with the balance?
I think Merlet VSOP would be delicious.

Really nice cocktail - pineapple juice is lead taste (as should be expected), with a bit of brightness from the lemon lifting the pineapple. I like how bourbon works with pineapple, but in this case I think the amaretto is a bit heavy in the final taste - I may tweak the proportions a bit to reduce the amaretto next time.

Nice!
Maybe a little more sweetness! Or my pineapple wasnt sweet enough.
Interesting, do actually like it. Wonder what the original recipe is
Made with Goslings, very tasty. Had sweet lime instead of the usual so bumped it up to 1/2 oz for extra tartness (lemon is essential too). A very different Daiquiri.
Used Myers's and all lime (out of lemon)... Rubber-y?... I think a lemon/lime split would help... Once it settles, it improves... Wouldn't be my go-to use for either dark rum or Cynar.

Only had Goslings 151 - added more simple syrup and did the shakin’ part for a full 25 sec to get more dilution. Result - very tasty, you get the rum flavor with a bit of bitterness from Cynar. I’ll make it again - but will drink slowly lol ;-)
Thanks for pointing out. I have switched rums appropriately.

I don't think the gentian overpowers like some comments say, but the lemon sure does. Would cut that down to 22.5 ml.

Otherwise, a great cocktail.
Wow. I enjoyed this. Did not feel Suze overpowered. Used rye and monte negro since I had them. Maybe a bit too tart but that could be my lemons. Refreshing on a 107 degree day
Saw the ingredient list and was so confused I felt I had to try it..and yeah this is Suze central. No identifiable bourbon or vanilla, just a whole lotta gentian.
I'd have to disagree with Robert, the Suze is the star of the show here and is overpowering the flavors. If you like Suze, you'll like this, otherwise look for something else.
I love it. The Suze does not over-power, in my opinion. I appreciate grew fact that its not sweet.
A curious fish. Definitely one for Suze lovers.

Subbed Montenegro for the Nonino. A bit too much lemon for my taste, but otherwise a great drink. I completely get the “not-hot-hot toddy” effect; I suspect if this were served hot, the proportion of lemon juice come closer to the mark.

Really amazing - your rum is central to the success of this cocktail. I used Smith and Cross (which is linked to Hampden) and the funky rum notes are displayed to fantastic effect! IMO, the other ingredients act to soften, sweeten and add some fruit to the rum - complementing the flavor while allowing the funkiness to come through. This is an exceptional cocktail for someone who really likes their Jamaican rum!
This is freaking awesome! Favorite cocktail off this site in a long time!
A top 5 favorite recipe from this site so far, and the best use that I've found for Byrrh.

Echoing others: my favourite sazerac. The balance of sweet, boozy, herbal and piquant is spot on. I went slightly scant on the sugar. The dilution is essential. Martell VSOP and Rittenhouse, bitter truth creole bitters.

Quite possibly the ideal Sazerac. More breadth, depth, and dynamic impact. And what a lovely, long finish that flames out with a fruity/spicy/dry aftertaste. I did use Cognac Leyrat VS and Old Overholt 114, neither of which would've been my go-to choice here. But, woof, did it turn out sublime.

This is far and away my absolute favorite sazerac. I was looking for a use for the gomme syrup I made just recently and this was an utterly spectacular use for it. This drink makes me enjoy a lot of things I don't normally enjoy, and I find that really remarkable.
Great twist on a Sazerac, one of my favorites. We need put in a little more Pernod. Fantastic.

Dangerously smooth! I used 114 proof rye and it's still mellow enough to drink easily. I don't think it's necessary to use a nicer Cognac like 1738, due to all the other ingredients imparting their own flavors. Drink it slow and enjoy.
De novo essa água...
It’s okay but I would drop the Elderflower down a tad, also the Bitters by a couple of drops 😂
Wonderful herbal and floral flavours. The sherry, vermouth, and bitters are forward here. Very pleasant cocktail and perfect for an aperitif.

Not a fan of tasteless vodka but made it according to recipe. Thought the sherry overpowered. Thought I'd try replacing the vodka with gin and had some Victoria Lane pink gin on hand which I thought would be springlike in color at least. A cocktail more balanced imo- sherry is put back in its place by the gin- and has a delicate pink blush from the gin.
Thank you so much! Cheers!
Would any of your brilliant bar tenders be able to share the measurements as a “pitcher”
Simply multiple the recipe according to the capaicity desired/or of your pitcher. Easier to work in ml. e.g. total ml of ingredients = 80ml x 6 = 480ml which with ice would suit average pitcher.

Yummy. Works very well with Sparkling rosè as well.
Suggestion: Try it without the bubbly as well.
Herbal and refreshing. Did find it a little sweet so we doubled the amount of Cava which brought down the sweetness for us. Next time may increase the lime juice to a full oz. Very enjoyable.
I found I had to double the cava too, but I’m not a big fan of The Last Word so take that with a grain of salt.

Who knew? Last Word plus bubbly. Excellent! Now I have to try Spanish Cava. (I made mine with brut rosé, a bit flat so I added extra.) Next stop; which sparkling wine to add to which variation of the last word. Five star fun!
This was perfect made with Cava and Génépy! Now to find the elusive Green Chartreuse.

Most enjoyable! Slight variation on ingredients based on availability in my bar; Patient Wolf dry gin, Maschio Prosecco, 1/3 shot lime juice. Chartreuse, Maraschino is a really intriguing combo. The sparkling, in this case Prosecco, was a great finish for texture - reminiscent of a more richly flavoured French 75. Very cool!
Haven't tried it yet, but if you like the Last Word then this should extend the time you can appreciate it and mellow the lovely intensity of the Chartreuse.

cocktail: The Last Time (AKA Stop Fiddling With My Drink)

comments.comment: Are there any more Paloma drinks? She's so much better at making up cocktails than that Simon guy.
You're too kind, although just perhaps I'm more at home on the other side of the bar!
I've checked and sadly this is the only Paloma original on Difford's Guide. In the meantime, we're all stuck with the stuff by that Simon guy.
I don't really like the taste of sherry, but this drink somehow makes the sherry very palatable - I think it's the coconut that does it - so don't be put off if you too don't like sherry!

As a devout lover of Strega, I had to give this lovely gin and citrus mix with a touch of Strega a shot. The drink is quite good, and I enjoyed it, but the thing that messed it up was the Strega and dry gin interaction. They didn't play particularly well together, though to be fair, I used a London Dry Gin in my test. But then I tried again with the softer, sweeter Old Tom Gin, and it was really great!
A little sweet, but good balance. I gave it 4-stars. After trying did a dark rum float (being a big rum drinker) and it was worth a 5. Not as sweet and still good balance.
Nice, cooling cocktail. Nothing spectacular. Thought it was missing an ingredient. Maybe an anejo tequila float. Not much tequila flavour.
Hi, maybe add Alabazam to a variations section, same on the Alabazam Page

A damn revelation! And I only made this because I just swiped a half pound of my neighbor's apples from a tree whose branches were hanging over into my yard. Fair game!... Not a Martini. ... Made this with Hayman's Old Tom, which was fortunately ideal... Great drink!
A Saturday night cocktail, aimed to please and not divide opinion.

What a delightfully refreshing cocktail. It was not what I was expecting when I looked at the ingredients. Everything blends together perfectly. It has a hint of grapefruit flavour. Definitely a keeper.
My husband mistakenly added creme de violette instead of elderflower. It was fabulous! Of course the color was fairly awful, but I named his version the Grey Flannel Suit.

Yeah, I know that technically there's still two days to go before this gets its "Cocktail of the Day" billing, but when I saw it on the horizon the name rang a tiny little bell somewhere. Well, I'm glad it did. You know when you've tasted something in the past, and you know you really enjoyed it, and weeks and months later you can't recall for the life of you which particular cocktail it was any more? (Well, okay, maybe that doesn't happen to those of you who are meticulous with notes...)

...Well, this was one of those cocktails, and the moment I sipped, it was like a reunion! Absolutely glorious fruity cocktail, and at last I'm glad I can add it to my favourites for future recall. Ringing a tiny little bell? No, more like celebrating the onset of autumn with a chamber orchestra playing one of your favourite tunes. A grand drink, and highly recommendable.
This cocktail works far better than you would think it would just by reading the ingredients. It's one of my all time favs.

When I've made this with Hayman's and Plymouth's Sloe Gins it was a solid five. Recently the best Sloe Gin I could find was Sipsmith. And for all thier talk about flavor variations from harvest years, the 2018 "special edition" was rather insipid in this cocktail. Maybe a dash of Cherry Heering would help.

Enjoyed very much. I am not a fan of too much smokey in my Scotch, and this one had just the right amount of smokey to other flavours. If you like the smokey more, I think Jon Pidwerbecki's suggestion may work well for you.

Tried as prescribed. Great. Dewars has a Smokey component. Sloe gin was a bit overpowering.
Built my own with 2 oz scotch and 1 oz sloe gin with same portion of prescription. Cleaner taste in my humble opinion
Very interesting, but I didn't find it good balanced. Less basil and more mandarin juice improved it. Maybe it would be a good idea to lift Bacardi and Benedictine?
I can’t believe I’m the first to review this but I won’t be the last. Tart and tasty. If you have a juicer juice the citrus fruit whole - it adds a background bitterness that works well
Thanks Sally. Reading your comment I noticed some stray copy on the page. Now fixed. Next time i have mandarins I'll be sure to try.

The recipe, as written, has too much Benedictine. The sherry shows up too late... Reduced the Bene' to 10 ml and - YES! - now the drinks sings. This triumph even with the most spineless strong rye I've ever tried, Old Overholt 114. Can't imagine how far it could excel with a Rittenhouse or Dad's Hat.
Delightful cocktail! The spicy qualities are warm and sparkling, which I love. But I did use a couple of dashes of Cardamon bitters, reducing the Angostura, and it was magnificent.
Excellent. Well balanced. Rich and spicy contrasting with cool herbal notes.
Strong spicy rye and plenty of Angostura lead this quartet.
I love it, let's face it, it's good. But to me, the bourbon is taking over both Giffard liqueurs (Vanille de Madagascar & Ginger of the Indies). I might try with 1 cl for both instead of 0,75 cl...
Wonderful evening sipper. A bit sweet but the bourbon still present. The mixture of the ingredients does result in a cocktail with bourbon and chocolate overtones. Very nice.
Followed Diffords guide which has 7.5 ml maple and I loved it. Felt a equal blend . I did use Bulleit Rye so maybe that compensated well. First use of my Madagascar vanilla…wow …awesome!
I would be careful that the maple syrup doesn’t overwhelm the other flavours. I dialled it back to a scant 5ml.
Agreed! I've cut the maple syrup back to 5ml.
gilbeys | bitter truth grapefruit bitters ... didnt like this, pretty bitter, clashing, so far i havent liked these bitters so that could be the problem or maybe i need better gin or vermouth
Very good, something like an aperitif disguised as a digestif. Surprisingly dry, and slightly bitter, and the grapefruit bitters are a nice touch.
Was looking for a good aperitivo to have before an Italian dinner. Nicely bitter with the herbal falvours from the gin. Grapefruit bitters add a slight hint of citrus. Not overly sweet.
Is that red or white vermouth? Not sure what an "Old Gin cocktail" is, but with red vermouth (my guess) this looks like a "dry" Negroni variation.

Finally got around to trying this, using Carpano Antica and the "low octane" (16.5%) version of Cynar, which I upped to 3/4 oz (same as the vermouth) so it wouldn't get lost. Left the gin at 1.75 oz for a "dry Negroni" effect. Cynar instead of Campari is a great variation, and the proportions make for a lighter, drier cocktail that lets the herbal aspects of the ingredients come through rather than being overwhelmed by sweet and bitter flavors. A great aperitivo, and a great kickoff to International Negroni Week (negroniweek.com) even though it doesn't use Campari.
Yup, sweet vermouth.

This blew away my expectations severalfold, whatever they may have been... Made this with Barrow's, Campari, Ango orange, and Fever Tree Tonic Water... Shot up to my top 25 maybe (at least top 50). Fantastic!
Doesn't taste alcoholic (which is a tad worrying..) but refreshing and delicious. Perhaps my favourite long drink, certainly one of.

Excuse me if this is a silly question, but lots of the recipes say “adapted from…” and I’m interested to know what “adapted from…” means?
How different is the recipe given from the original?
This is a lovely drink by the way.

“Adapted from is something I add to pretty much all origins now as there is almost always some change from the original recipe, some as small as fine straining or not fine straining through to more significant changes in measures or ingredients. It also frees me to stipulate brands that may not have originally been used. I now also tend to add the original recipe or a note to highlight and significant change I’ve made.”
for a long drink, this is simply ideal; sweet spicy ginger, balanced with bitter, and a hint of citrus. wonderful!
60ml of tq makes it a drink
For me, the Cointreau overpowered the drink. I used Don Julio 70 and it overpowered it. I think this is the first time I will disagree with John (LOL)

Respectfully, with an additive laden Cristalino, of course it will end up like that. Even the standard Don Julio Blanco tends to be too hidden. This is a Margarita which truly needs a vegetal, mineral and/or citrus-y additive free Blanco Tequila. I opened my Cascahuin Blanco and tried this first, and it was really good, with it being balanced towards the very tart side.

Having spent the last 50 years in Southern California, I have drank a lot of margarita. I always find them a bit too sweet and flat in flavour. This was off the charts for me. It is simple, and bright and clean in flavour. Nicely sour as if you have taken a shot of tequila with a taste of lime. I will definitely have this one again. We did add Difford's Margarita Bitters which nicely embellished a wonderful cocktail.
No Orgeat so subbed 7.5ml of Disaronno. Will try walnut liqueur. A lovely, refreshing dram.
Excellent, it's got a pomegranite vibe. A little extra gin doesn't hurt.
Delicious!

A pleasing bitter-sweet drink, contrasting the sweet Orgeat with lemon juice. I usually don't manage egg-white components and so found the cocktail a little "heavy" without. A little extra chilled water compensated very successfully and added a light touch.
I added a dash of Campari - made a bit less sweet. Can recommend it.

Oh, this was delicious! I actually made it with spiced rum, as that’s what I had on hand, and while I suppose that’s a whole other drink, it was very good - moved from afternoon aperitif to cozy vanilla-infused winter evening drink.

Excellent afternoon libation, especially if the sun is shining! I dialled the lemon juice back just a little, which left it slightly sweeter, but also more balanced I felt. And lacking an atomiser for bitters, three drops on top of the frothy top looks aesthetically pleasing, and really brings it all together (as I'm sure atomised Angostura would have done!).

Tastes like raspberry jam with a nice warming bourbon linger at the end. Sublime.

I do agree that it needs less sugar syrup.

Why is there sugar syrup in this? Just made this twice, back to back. Replace the volume of syrup with and equal measure of creme de mure. Much more dynamic and vibrant. The bourbon-blackberry-mint combo actually exceeded my expectations. But, really, what was I thinking? Of course it's sublime. (2 Jul 2022, 1:38p)

I wish I could feel the brilliance. I made it with the original Scotch utilised, the Glenlivet 12. A strange mustiness (the malt probably) ruined the entire balance of the drink, with that being the starting point, rounded out by the much more pleasant honey and lime. Strange drink.
@Simon Difford Tried it again with this new recipe. Much, much better. It makes more sense now. I think the lemon pairs better than the lime with the Speyside Single Malt.
Hi Chris. Try now. I've subtly rebalanced and split the citrus between lime and lemon. I've rated 4.5/5.
Very nice citrus forward cocktail with the hit of the Scotch Whisky in the back. Very smooth and easy to drink. All-in-all excellent.

If you ever wondered what a scotch margarita tastes like, this is pretty darn close.
My non-tequila drinking wife approved

The "cocktail of the day" intro names Sept 30th, 1912, as an auspicious day in the Robert Scott tragedy. However, his attempt to walk out of Antartica began on actually began on January 19th. He walked the first 300 miles by February 7th. 20 days later, they still had 300 miles to go and reached the spot where they died on March 19th. It is estimated that he died 10-11 days later.

I think you are referring to Scott. However, on our Cocktail of the Day page, we are referring to the party of 6, “Northern Party”, who were left in the vicinity of “Evans Cove” on the 4th of January, and they were meant to be picked up on Feb the 18th. But due to heavy pack ice the ship never made it. There was an attempt to relieve the “Northern Party” on 17th of April however they were beaten by the weather. Their walk back to base camp started on 30th September, and they reached Cape Evans on 7th of November.

( continuation of post below) To obtain this bouquet we distil by micro-part, which is not possible in large industrial processes, and rums from Marie Galante are produced in small quantities.

Just to clarify, ti- punch is a cocktail that was created on the island of Marie Galante (one of the islands that make up Guadeloupe) on 27 April 1848 to celebrate the abolition of slavery in France.
It was composed using rum from Marie Galante (Guadeloupe). The special thing about these rums is that their fragrance bouquet is much more powerful, fruity and fresh than other agricultural rums.

Poison Dart - Best Tiki Drink Ever!

INGREDIENTS
2 oz Bourbon
.5 oz Fresh Lemon Juice
.5 oz Orgeat (Try El Guapo Creole Orgeat)
.25 oz Cinnamon Syrup
.25 oz Cynar
1 dash Orange BItters
1 dash Allspice Dram
Orange twist (for garnish)
INSTRUCTIONS
Shake all ingredients with ice and strain into a coupe glass.
Garnish the edge of the glass with an orange twist.

It is counterintuitive to use hot fresh espresso, but espresso that has been allowed to cool is more acidic and lacks the flavour of freshly made espresso. With good ice, over dilution is not an issue. However, if you don’t have an espresso machine, then there are some purpose-made coffee concentrates available, e.g. https://www.diffordsguide.com/beer-wine-spirits/6790/solo-coffee-cold-brew-concentrate

Many people say “Embury had a dry palate” but I’m not convinced that is correct.
Cocktail recipes usually state simple syrup (1:1 sugar and water) or strong simple syrup (2:1 sugar and water) but on page 101 of my copy of David Embury’s “Fine Art of Mixing Drinks” he says “I have found that a mixture of 3 cups of sugar to each cup of water yields a very satisfactory syrup.” So he’s really using 3 measures of simple syrup when he calls for 1 part of sugar syrup in his recipes. That’s not dry!

Embury does call for a 3:1 syrup, but that is not three times as sweet as a 1:1 syrup. For example, if a recipe states 10ml (1/3oz) of 2:1 rich sugar syrup, then the equivalent in 1:1 simple syrup is just 15ml (½oz), not 20ml, as you might expect. I have experimented with Embury’s 3:1 syrup, and it is too thick to pour out of a measure without leaving an unknown percentage in the jigger. It also tends to crystallise.

Finding the perfect capacity glass for each cocktail is a task, and most modern coupes are a little on the large side. The ingredients total 105ml plus 36% dilution from shaking with ice = 143ml. A 7-oz coupe glass has a capacity of 200ml to the rim, so it would be 70% (roughly 2/3rds) full. If you are not achieving roughly this capacity, then perhaps your ice needs to be left to temper, and/or a more vigorous shake is required.
